title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #643** asks about hypergraphs and 'crossed pairs'.

Given a t-uniform hypergraph, find the minimum number of edges f(n;t) that forces four edges A,B,C,D satisfying:
- A ∪ B = C ∪ D
- A ∩ B = C ∩ D = ∅

The conjecture: f(n;t) = (1+o(1))·C(n,t-1) for t ≥ 3.
mathContext: f(n;t) = min{m : every t-uniform H with m edges contains a crossed pair}

title: Hypergraph Definitions
content:
**Hypergraph V** is defined as `Set (Finset V)` - a collection of subsets of vertices.

**IsUniform H t** holds if all edges have exactly t vertices.

**edgeCount H** is the number of edges (using Set.ncard for cardinality).
mathContext: A t-uniform hypergraph is a collection of t-element subsets of a vertex set.

title: Crossed Pair Configuration
content:
**IsCrossedPair A B C D** holds when:
1. A ∪ B = C ∪ D (same union)
2. A ∩ B = ∅ (first pair disjoint)
3. C ∩ D = ∅ (second pair disjoint)
4. {A,B} ≠ {C,D} (different pairing)

This is the forbidden configuration we're trying to force.
mathContext: Four edges partition the same 2t-element set in two different ways.

title: The Extremal Function
content:
**f(n,t)** is defined as the minimum m such that any t-uniform hypergraph on n vertices with at least m edges must contain a crossed pair.

We use Nat.find to select the least such m, with existence proven by noting that the total number of t-subsets is finite.
mathContext: f(n,t) = min{m : ∀H t-uniform on n vertices, |H| ≥ m → HasCrossedPair H}

title: Case t = 2: Connection to C4
content:
**For graphs (t=2)**, a crossed pair is essentially a 4-cycle!

The four 2-element edges form an alternating path v1-v2-v3-v4-v1.

The **Kovari-Sos-Turan theorem** gives f(n,2) = O(n^{3/2}), connecting this to classical extremal graph theory.
mathContext: C4-free graphs have at most (1/2 + o(1))n^{3/2} edges.

title: Pikhurko-Verstrate Bound
content:
**Pikhurko-Verstrate (2009)** proved that for 3-uniform hypergraphs:

f(n,3) <= (13/9)*C(n,2)

This is the best known upper bound for the 3-uniform case and represents significant progress toward the conjecture.

title: General Bounds
content:
**Lower bound**: f(n,t) >= C(n-1,t-1) + floor((n-1)/t)

This comes from sunflower constructions.

**Upper bound**: f(n,t) < (7/2)*C(n,t-1)

The gap between these bounds is what the conjecture aims to close.

title: The Main Conjecture
content:
**Erdos Problem #643** (OPEN): For t >= 3,

lim_{n->inf} f(n,t) / C(n,t-1) = 1

Equivalently, f(n,t) = (1 + o(1))*C(n,t-1).

This would show sunflower constructions are asymptotically optimal.
mathContext: Erdos643Conjecture := forall t>=3, Tendsto (fun n => f(n,t)/C(n,t-1)) atTop (nhds 1)

title: Sunflower Construction
content:
**SunflowerHypergraph** is the key construction for lower bounds.

All edges share a common (t-1)-element **core**.
Each edge adds one unique element from the **petals** set.

This gives approximately C(n-1,t-1) edges with no crossed pairs.
mathContext: Edges have form core U {p} for p in petals, where |core| = t-1.

title: Sunflowers Have No Crossed Pairs
content:
**Key Insight**: A sunflower cannot contain crossed pairs!

**Proof sketch**: Any two edges in a sunflower intersect in the core. For a crossed pair, we need A cap B = empty. But since t >= 2, the core has size >= 1, so any two edges share at least one vertex.

This contradiction shows sunflowers are crossed-pair-free.
mathContext: forall A,B in Sunflower: A cap B contains core != empty

title: Small Cases
content:
**f(4,2) = 3**: With 4 vertices and 3 edges, we can avoid a 4-cycle. With 4 edges (K4), we must have one.

**f(5,2) = 5**: Related to the Petersen graph, a famous 3-regular graph avoiding 4-cycles.
mathContext: Exact values known for small parameters.

title: Erdos-Rado Sunflower Lemma
content:
**The Sunflower Lemma** (Erdos-Rado 1960): Any sufficiently large k-uniform family contains a sunflower with r petals.

Specifically: there exists F(k) such that any k-uniform family with > F(k) * (r-1)^k members contains an r-sunflower.

This structural result constrains what large hypergraphs can look like.
mathContext: Large uniform families must contain sunflowers - a foundational result.
